image.altText: Fires burning in bushland in Tara, Queensland.

items.synopsis: After two days of cooler temperatures, firefighters in south-western Queensland are on high alert today, with hot weather and strong winds expected to make for dangerous fire conditions. Follow live.

title.children: More than 50 homes lost in Queensland blazes, as authorities warn 'these are the type of fires that will take a life'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Johanna Marie Queensland Police are evacuating residents and school students with a large bushfire burning at Goodwood, south of Bundaberg. Waterbombing is underway with more than 37 fire and emergency crews attending the blaze. It's understood the bushfire has jumped Goodwood Road, and police are door-knocking properties on Gorza Road and Peirson Road. Students and teachers at Goodwood State School have been evacuated by Education Queensland. An evacuation centre has been set up at the Isis Cultural Centre at Childers.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: School students and residents evacuated from Goodwood as large bushfire burns

children.content: Reporting by Johanna Marie

props.alt: Goodwood Road is closed, south of Bundaberg, where a bushfire has jumped containment lines.

children.content: Goodwood Road is closed, south of Bundaberg, where a bushfire has jumped containment lines.
(ABC News: Johanna Marie)

properties on Gorza Road and Peirson Road.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Fire and Emergency Services has extended a local fire ban for North Coast region residents. The local fire ban will be in place until one minute before midnight on Monday, November 6. The local fire ban also includes residents in the Sunshine Coast and Noosa local government areas, along with the Bundaberg, Fraser Coast, Gympie, North Burnett, South Burnett and Cherbourg local government areas.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fire ban extended for residents on the Sunshine Coast, Noosa, Bundaberg and beyond

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An emergency warning is in place for Wallangarra township, with a "potentially deadly fire" impacting it now. QFES has warned: "Your life is in danger. You need to SEEK SHELTER IMMEDIATELY to survive." Do not try to leave. Driving now could be deadly. You should seek shelter immediately: Inside a brick building In a room with multiple escape points On the opposite side from the approaching fire. As the fire approaches and passes, the safest place will change, so be ready to move quickly.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: People in Wallangarra township need to seek shelter immediately

props.alt: The Wallangarra fire, as seen from Lyra, about 15 kilometres north.

children.content: The Wallangarra fire, as seen from Lyra, about 15 kilometres north.

title.children: More than 1.4 million displaced in Gaza as all 13 hospitals given evacuation orders, UN says

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An Israeli government ministry has drafted a wartime proposal to transfer the Gaza Strip's 2.3 million people to Egypt's Sinai Peninsula, drawing condemnation from the Palestinians and worsening tensions with Cairo. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office played down the report compiled by the Intelligence Ministry as a hypothetical exercise — a "concept paper". The document is dated October 13 and was first published by Sicha Mekomit, a local news site. In its report, the Intelligence Ministry — a junior ministry that conducts research but does not set policy — offered three alternatives "to effect a significant change in the civilian reality in the Gaza Strip in light of the Hamas crimes that led to the Sword of Iron war". The document's authors deem this alternative to be the most desirable for Israel's security. The document proposes moving Gaza's civilian population to tent cities in northern Sinai, then building permanent cities and an undefined humanitarian corridor. A security zone would be established inside Israel to block the displaced Palestinians from entering. The report did not say what would become of Gaza once its population is cleared out. AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli ministry drafts plan to transfer Gaza civilians to Egypt

children.content: An Israeli government ministry has drafted a wartime proposal to transfer the Gaza Strip's 2.3 million people to Egypt's Sinai Peninsula, drawing condemnation from the Palestinians and worsening tensions with Cairo.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office played down the report compiled by the Intelligence Ministry as a hypothetical exercise — a "concept paper".

props.alt: People walk through rubble in ruined streets.

children.content: (AP Photo: Abed Khaled)
The document is dated October 13 and was first published by Sicha Mekomit, a local news site.

In its report, the Intelligence Ministry — a junior ministry that conducts research but does not set policy — offered three alternatives "to effect a significant change in the civilian reality in the Gaza Strip in light of the Hamas crimes that led to the Sword of Iron war".
The document's authors deem this alternative to be the most desirable for Israel's security.
The document proposes moving Gaza's civilian population to tent cities in northern Sinai, then building permanent cities and an undefined humanitarian corridor.
A security zone would be established inside Israel to block the displaced Palestinians from entering.
The report did not say what would become of Gaza once its population is cleared out.
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's United Nations ambassador displayed a yellow star on his chest as he addressed the Security Council, provocatively pledging to wear the badge until members of the body condemn Hamas "atrocities". "Some of you have learned nothing in the past 80 years. Some of you have forgotten why this body was established," envoy Gilad Erdan said, as he denounced the Security Council for "staying silent" over Hamas's October 7 attacks. The deeply divided 15-member council has not adopted a single resolution on the three-week-long war between Israel and Hamas. "So, I will remind you. From this day on, each time you look at me you will remember what staying silent in the face of evil means," the ambassador said. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel envoy wears yellow star at UN, accuses Security Council of 'staying silent'

children.content: Israel's United Nations ambassador displayed a yellow star on his chest as he addressed the Security Council, provocatively pledging to wear the badge until members of the body condemn Hamas "atrocities".

props.alt: Gilad Erdan sits at a table wearing a yellow star of David reading "Never Again"

children.content: (AP Photo: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez )

"Some of you have learned nothing in the past 80 years. Some of you have forgotten why this body was established," envoy Gilad Erdan said, as he denounced the Security Council for "staying silent" over Hamas's October 7 attacks.
The deeply divided 15-member council has not adopted a single resolution on the three-week-long war between Israel and Hamas.
"So, I will remind you. From this day on, each time you look at me you will remember what staying silent in the face of evil means," the ambassador said.
AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The head of the UN's agency for Palestinian refugees warns "an immediate humanitarian ceasefire has become a matter of life and death for millions". The United Nations Relief and Works Agency's Philippe Lazzarini stressed "the present and future of Palestinians and Israelis depend on it". He warned during an emergency meeting of the UN's Security Council that a further breakdown of civil order, following the recent break-ins at the agency's warehouses by panicked Palestinians searching for food and other aid, will make it extremely difficult for the UNRWA to continue operating. Mr Lazzarini said most Palestinians in Gaza "feel trapped in a war they have nothing to do with" and "they feel the world is equating all of them to Hamas". Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Immediate ceasefire 'a matter of life and death'

children.content: The head of the UN's agency for Palestinian refugees warns "an immediate humanitarian ceasefire has become a matter of life and death for millions".
The United Nations Relief and Works Agency's Philippe Lazzarini stressed "the present and future of Palestinians and Israelis depend on it".

He warned during an emergency meeting of the UN's Security Council that a further breakdown of civil order, following the recent break-ins at the agency's warehouses by panicked Palestinians searching for food and other aid, will make it extremely difficult for the UNRWA to continue operating.
Mr Lazzarini said most Palestinians in Gaza "feel trapped in a war they have nothing to do with" and "they feel the world is equating all of them to Hamas".
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Offshore Alliance members working on three Chevron gas facilities in Western Australia — Gorgon, Wheatstone Platform and Wheatstone Downstream — have voted in favour of three proposed Enterprise Bargaining Agreements (EBA) with the company. The Offshore Alliance is an alliance between The Australian Workers' Union (AWU) and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA). It says the agreements deliver members secure jobs, fixed rosters, career progression and significant improvements in pay and conditions of employment. For Gorgon and Wheatstone Downstream, the Offshore Alliance was negotiating on behalf of its members with Chevron since the start of 2023, and since mid-2022 for its members at the Wheatstone Platform. AWU WA secretary Brad Gandy says Offshore Alliance members at Chevron never blinked during negotiations. "Subjective behavioural standards, which have previously prevented members progressing through the classification structure, are gone. Career progression will now be competency based," he said in a statement. "Forty per cent rosters are now locked in for all employees, which means those coerced by Chevron during COVID to move to a 50 per cent roster will transferred to their previous, more family friendly roster. "Chevron employees now have union representation, arbitration of disputes in the Fair Work Commission, improved overcycle provisions and significantly enhanced training provisions, including additional payment, allowances and the right to refuse additional work."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chevron workers endorse pay deal

children.content: Offshore Alliance members working on three Chevron gas facilities in Western Australia — Gorgon, Wheatstone Platform and Wheatstone Downstream — have voted in favour of three proposed Enterprise Bargaining Agreements (EBA) with the company.
The Offshore Alliance is an alliance between The Australian Workers' Union (AWU) and the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA).
It says the agreements deliver members secure jobs, fixed rosters, career progression and significant improvements in pay and conditions of employment.

For Gorgon and Wheatstone Downstream, the Offshore Alliance was negotiating on behalf of its members with Chevron since the start of 2023, and since mid-2022 for its members at the Wheatstone Platform.
AWU WA secretary Brad Gandy says Offshore Alliance members at Chevron never blinked during negotiations.

"Subjective behavioural standards, which have previously prevented members progressing through the classification structure, are gone. Career progression will now be competency based," he said in a statement.

"Forty per cent rosters are now locked in for all employees, which means those coerced by Chevron during COVID to move to a 50 per cent roster will transferred to their previous, more family friendly roster.

"Chevron employees now have union representation, arbitration of disputes in the Fair Work Commission, improved overcycle provisions and significantly enhanced training provisions, including additional payment, allowances and the right to refuse additional work."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After a spectacular crash, the world's most recognisable cryptocurrency is booming again. The market price of bitcoin is back to almost half of its former glory and other cryptocurrencies are along for the ride. Business reporter Emilia Terzon explains why. You can also watch the story on The Business program tonight at 8:45pm AEDT on ABC News channel or stream on ABC iview.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bitcoin leading the charge of cryptocurrencies

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, helped by gains in energy and financial stocks, while traders awaited the US central bank's policy meeting this week for further interest rate clues. The ASX 200 index advanced 0.3 per cent or 20 points, to 6,793 by 1:37pm AEDT after hitting a more than one-year low on Monday. The US Federal Reserve is expected to leave policy rates on hold at the end of its two-day meeting starting later in the day. Market participants will focus on the message from Fed policymakers to gauge the interest rate outlook. Meanwhile, retail sales in Australia rose at the fastest pace in eight months in September, suggesting resilience in consumer spending which would add to the case for an interest rate hike at the Australian central bank's policy meeting on November 7. Investors are also looking out for a survey of purchasing managers in China's manufacturing segment later in the day to assess the economic recovery of Australia's top trading partner. A Reuters poll showed China's manufacturing activity likely expanded for a second straight month in October. In Sydney, interest rate-sensitive financials rose 0.7 per cent, with the big four banks gaining between 0.5 per cent and 0.7 per cent. Energy stocks jumped 0.3 per cent, with Woodside Energy and Santos up 0.8 per cent and 0.9 per cent, respectively. Technology stocks tracked their Wall Street peers higher, gaining 0.1 per cent. Shares of Xero jumped 0.3 per cent. Gold stocks slid 1.3 per cent, with miner Northern Star Resources losing 2.7 per cent. Among individual stocks, Origin Energy fell 0.6 per cent after superannuation fund AustralianSuper said it plans to vote against a Brookfield-led consortium's $US9.78 billion takeover offer for the company. In corporate news, winemaker Treasury Wine agreed to a $US900 million buyout of California's DAOU Vineyards. Trading in its shares was halted.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX is still tracking higher in afternoon trade
